The severity of a message. Note: This field is a string. Please use aseverity_id field for severity ID fields that are integer data types. Specific values are required. Please use vendor_severity for the vendor's own human-readable strings (such as Good, Bad, Really Bad, and so on).
A numeric severity indicator for a message.

Service or daemon names belong to the service field (see below). Also, note that this field is a string. Please use a process_id field for process ID fields that are integer data types.

The name of the service, such as SQL Server or Apache Web Server. Note: This field is not appropriate for filenames, such as sqlsrvr.exe orhttpd. Filenames should belong to the process field instead. Also, note that field is a string. Please use theservice_id field for service ID fields that are integer data types.

The target involved in the authentication. You canalias this from more specific fields, such asdest_host, dest_ip, or dest_nt_host.
The business unit of the authentication target. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The category of the authentication target, such asemail_server or SOX-compliant. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.
The name of the Active Directory used by the authentication target, if applicable.
The priority of the authentication target.
The amount of time for the completion of the authentication event, in seconds.
The human-readable message associated with the authentication action (success or failure).
The amount of time it took to receive a response in the authentication event, in seconds.
A human-readable signature name.
The unique identifier or event code of the event signature.

The source involved in the authentication. In the case of endpoint protection authentication thesrc is the client. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as src_host, src_ip, orsrc_nt_host. Note: Do not confuse src with the event sourceor sourcetype fields.
The business unit of the authentication source. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The category of the authentication source, such asemail_server or SOX-compliant. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.
The name of the Active Directory used by the authentication source, if applicable.
The priority of the authentication source.
In privilege escalation events, src_userrepresents the user who initiated the privilege escalation. This field is unnecessary when an escalation has not been performed.
The business unit of the user who initiated the privilege escalation. This field is unnecessary when an escalation has not been performed.
The category of the user who initiated the privilege escalation. This field is unnecessary when an escalation has not been performed.
The unique id of the user who initiated the privilege escalation.
The priority of the user who initiated the privilege escalation. This field is unnecessary when an escalation has not been performed.
The role of the user who initiated the privilege escalation. This field is unnecessary when an escalation has not been performed
The type of the user who initiated the privilege escalation. This field is unnecessary when an escalation has not been performed
A tag associated with the authentication event.
The name of the user involved in the event, or who initiated the event. For authentication privilege escalation events this should represent the user targeted by the escalation.
The user agent through which the request was made. (Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_6))
The business unit of the user involved in the event, or who initiated the event. For authentication privilege escalation events this should represent the user targeted by the escalation.
The category of the user involved in the event, or who initiated the event. For authentication privilege escalation events this should represent the user targeted by the escalation.
The unique id of the user involved in the event. For authentication privilege escalation events, this should represent the user targeted by the escalation.
The priority of the user involved in the event, or who initiated the event. For authentication privilege escalation events this should represent the user targeted by the escalation.
The role of the user involved in the event, or who initiated the event. For authentication privilege escalation events, this should represent the user role targeted by the escalation.

The type of the user involved in the event or who initiated the event. (IAMUser, Admin, or System). For authentication privilege escalation events, this should represent the user type targeted by the escalation.
The account that manages the user that initiated the request. The account represents the organization, a Cloud customer, or a Cloud account

The priority of the target.

The amount of time it took to receive a response in the certificate management event, if applicable.

The category of the certificate management source, such as email_server or SOX-compliant. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The certificateÕs serial number.
The session identifier for this certificate.
The algorithm used by the Certificate Authority to sign the certificate.
This is the start date and time for this certificate's validity.

This certificate ownerÕs common name.
The certificate ownerÕs e-mail address.

The ssl version of this certificate.

The type of change, such asfilesystem or AAA(authentication, authorization, and accounting).
The command that initiated the change.
The resource where change occurred. You can alias this from more specific fields, such asdest_host, dest_ip, ordest_name.

The device that reported the change, if applicable, such as a FIP or CIM server. You can alias this from more specific fields, such asdvc_host, dvc_ip, or dvc_name.
Name of the affected object on the resource (such as a router interface, user account, or server volume).
The attributes that were updated on the updated resource object, if applicable.
Generic name for the class of the updated resource object. Expected values may be specific to an App.
The unique updated resource object ID as presented to the system, if applicable (for instance, a SID, UUID, or GUID value).
The path of the modified resource object, if applicable (such as a file, directory, or volume).

The vendor-specific result of a change, or clarification of anaction status. For instance,status=failure may be accompanied by result=blocked by policy or result=disk full. Note: result is a string. Please use a msg_severity_idfield for severity ID fields that are integer data types.
A result indicator for an actionstatus.
The resource where the change was originated. You can alias this from more specific fields, such assrc_host, src_ip, or src_name.

The NT domain of the destination, if applicable.

Name of the database process user.
The business unit of the user.
The category associated with the user.
The priority of the user.
The vendor product name of the database system. You can extract this from the fieldsvendor and product in the raw event data, if available.
The name of the database instance.
The version of the database instance.
The maximum number of processes that the database instance can handle.
The maximum number of sessions that the database instance can handle.
The status of the database server.
The average number of executions for the database instance.
The amount of the database dump area that has been used.
The total number of reads for the database instance.
The total number of writes for the database instance.
The total number of users for the database instance.
The number of processes currently running for the database instance.
The total number of sessions currently in use for the database instance.
The total size of the buffer cache for the database instance, in bytes.
The maximum number of number of buffers that can be hit in the database instance without finding a free buffer.
The hit-to-miss ratio for the database instance's data dictionary.
The size of the fixed area (also referred to as the fixed SGA) for the database instance, in bytes.
The total amount of free memory in the database instance SGA, in bytes.
The total library cache size for the database instance, in bytes.
The total size of the redo log buffer for the database instance, in bytes
The total size of the shared pool for this database instance, in bytes.
The total size of the SQL area for this database instance, in bytes.
The total amount of uptime for the database instance.
The total amount of tablespace used for the database instance, in bytes.
The percentage of logical reads from the buffer during the session (1-physical reads/session logical reads*100).
The number of commits per second performed by the user associated with the session.
The number of CPU centiseconds used by the session. Divide this value by 100 to get the CPU seconds.
The number of the cursor currently in use by the session.
The total amount of time elapsed since the user started the session by logging into the database server, in seconds.
The total number of consistent gets and database block gets performed during the session.
The name of the logical host associated with the database instance.
The total number of memory sorts performed during the session.
The total number of physical reads performed during the session.

The description ofseconds_in_wait depends on the value of wait_time. Ifwait_time = 0,seconds_in_wait is the number of seconds spent in the current wait condition. Ifwait_time has a nonzero value, seconds_in_wait is the number of seconds that have elapsed since the start of the last wait. You can get the active seconds that have elapsed since the last wait ended by calculating seconds_in_wait - wait_time / 100.
The unique id that identifies the session.
The current status of the session.
Number of table scans performed during the session.
Provides the current wait state for the session. Can indicate that the session is currently waiting or provide information about the session's last wait.
possible_values: WAITING (the session is currently waiting), WAITED UNKNOWN TIME (the duration of the last session wait is unknown),WAITED SHORT TIME (the last session wait was < 1/100th of a second), WAITED KNOWN TIME(the wait_time is the duration of the last session wait).

description: When wait_time = 0, the session is waiting. Whenwait_time has a nonzero value, it is displaying the last wait time for the session.

Represents the amount of time elapsed since thesession_status changed to its current status. The definition of this field depends on thesession_status value. Ifsession_status = ONLINE, the last_call_minute value represents the time elapsed since the session became active. If session_status = OFFLINE, the last_call_minute value represents the time elapsed since the session became inactive.
The mode of the lock on the object.
The session identifier of the locked object.
The database logon time for the session.
The name of the locked object.
The process identifier for the operating system.
The mode of the lock on the object.
The full database query.
The identifier for the database query.
The time the system initiated the database query.
The number of records affected by the database query.
The total amount of free space in the tablespace, in bytes.
The name of the tablespace.
The number of tablespace reads carried out by the query.
The status of the tablespace.
The number of tablespace writes carried out by the query.
The names of the index or indexes hit by the database query.
The name of the query plan hist by the query.
The names of the stored procedures called by the query.
The names of the tables hit by the query.
Action taken by the reporting device.
Total sending delay in milliseconds.
The endpoint system to which the message was delivered. You can aliasthis from more specific fields, such asdest_host, dest_ip, or dest_name.
The business unit of the endpoint system to which the message was delivered.
The category of the endpoint system to which the message was delivered.
The priority of the endpoint system to which the message was delivered.
The amount of time for the completion of the messaging event, in seconds.
The hash(es) for the file(s) attached to the message, if any exist.
The name(s) of the file(s) attached to the message, if any exist.
The size of the file(s) attached the message, if they exist..
Host-specific unique message identifier (such as aid in sendmail, IMI in Domino, Internal-Message-ID in Exchange, and MID in Ironport).
The globally-unique message identifier.
Additional information about the message.
The original destination host of the message. The message destination host can change when a message is relayed or bounced.
The original recipient of the message. The message recipient can change when the original email address is an alias and has to be resolved to the actual recipient.
The original source of the message.
The name of the email executable that carries out the message transaction, such as sendmail, postfix, or the name of an email client.
The numeric identifier of the process invoked to send the message.
The email protocol involved, such asSMTP or RPC.
A field listing individual recipient email addresses, such asrecipient="foo@splunk.com",recipient="bar@splunk.com".
The total number of intended message recipients.
The recipient delivery status, if available.
The amount of time it took to receive a response in the messaging event, if applicable.
The number of times that the message was automatically resent because it was bounced back, or a similar transmission error condition.
The return address for the message.
The size of the message, in bytes.
The system that sent the message. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as src_host, src_ip, orsrc_name.
The business unit of the system that sent the message.
The category of the system that sent the message.
The priority of the system that sent the message.
The email address of the message sender.
The business unit of the message sender.
The category of the message sender.
The priority of the message sender.
The status code associated with the message.
The subject of the message.
The tag(s) associated with the message, if any exist.
The URL associated with the message, if any.
The user context for the process. This is not the email address for the sender. For that, look at the src_user field.
The business unit of the user context for the process.
The category of the user context for theprocess.
The priority of the user context for theprocess.
The vendor of the email server used for the email transaction.
Extended delay information for the message transaction. May contain details of all the delays from all the servers in the message transmission chain.
An external reference. Can contain message IDs or recipient addresses from related messages.
The status produced by the filter, such as "accepted", "rejected", or "dropped".
Numeric indicator assigned to specific emails by an email filter.
The name of the filter applied.
Any additional information about the filter.
The id associated with the filter name.
The destination of the message. You canalias this from more specific fields, such asdest_host, dest_ip, or dest_name.
The business unit of the destination.
The type of message destination.
The priority of the destination.
The number of seconds from message call to message response. Can be derived by getting the difference between therequest_sent_time and themessage_received_time.
The endpoint that the message accessed during the RPC (remote procedure call) transaction.
The version of the endpoint accessed during the RPC (remote procedure call) transaction, such as 1.0 or 1.22.
A command or reference that an RPC (remote procedure call) reads or responds to.
The time that the RPC (remote procedure call) read the message and was prepared to take some sort of action.
The message correlation identification value.
The time that the message producer sent the message.

The message delivery mode. Possible values depend on the type of message-oriented middleware (MOM) solution in use. They can be words like Transient (meaning the message is stored in memory and is lost if the server dies or restarts) or Persistent(meaning the message is stored both in memory and on disk and is preserved if the server dies or restarts). They can also be numbers like 1, 2, and so on.
The time that the message expired.
The message identification.
The priority of the message. Important jobs that the message queue should answer no matter what receive a highermessage_priority than other jobs, ensuring they are completed before the others.
An arbitrary list of message properties. The set of properties displayed depends on the message-oriented middleware (MOM) solution that you are using.
The time that the message was received by a message-oriented middleware (MOM) solution.
Indicates whether or not the message was redelivered.
The name of the destination for replies to the message.
The type of message, such as call orreply.
Arguments that have been passed to an endpoint by a REST call or something similar. A sample parameter could be something likefoo=bar.
The message payload.
The type of payload in the message. The payload type can be text (such as json,xml, and raw) or binary (such ascompressed, object, encrypted, andimage).
The content of the message request.
The type of payload in the message request. The payload type can be text (such as json,xml, and raw) or binary (such ascompressed, object, encrypted, andimage).
The time that the message request was sent.
The response status code sent by the receiving server. Ranges between 200 and404.
The type of payload in the message response. The payload type can be text (such as json, xml, and raw) or binary (such ascompressed, object, encrypted, andimage).
The time that the message response was received.
The amount of time it took to receive a response, in seconds.
The response status message sent by the message server.
The protocol that the message server uses for remote procedure calls (RPC). Possible values include HTTP REST, SOAP, and EJB.
The status of the message response.
Tags associated with the message.
The action taken by the intrusion detection system (IDS).

The vendor-provided category of the triggered signature, such as spyware. Note: This field is a string. Use acategory_id field for category ID fields that are integer data types (category_idfields are optional, so they are not included in this table).
The destination of the attack detected by the intrusion detection system (IDS). You can alias this from more specific fields, such as dest_host, dest_ip, ordest_name.

Also, specific values are required for this field. Usevendor_severity for the vendor's own human readable severity strings (such asGood, Bad, and Really Bad).

The source involved in the attack detected by the IDS. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as src_host,src_ip, or src_name.

The description of the inventory system.
The system where the data originated, the source of the event. You can alias this from more specific fields, such asdest_host, dest_ip, or dest_name.

Indicates whether the resource is enabled or disabled.
The product family of the resource, such as 686_64 or RISC.
The hypervisor identifier, if applicable.
The serial number of the resource.
The current reported state of the resource.
Splunk uses this automatically generated field to access tags from within data models. You do not need to populate it.
The vendor and product name of the resource, such as Cisco Catalyst 3850.
The version of a computer resource, such as 2008r2 or3.0.0.
The number of CPU cores reported by the resource (total, not per CPU).
The number of CPUs reported by the resource.
The maximum speed of the CPU reported by the resource (in megahertz).
The total amount of memory installed in or allocated to the resource, in megabytes.
The IP address for the system that the data is going to.
The domain name server for the resource.
Identifies whether the resource is a network address translation pool.
The network interfaces of the computing resource, such aseth0, eth1 or Wired Ethernet Connection, Teredo Tunneling Pseudo-Interface.
The network addresses of the computing resource, such as192.168.1.1 orE80:0000:0000:0000:0202:B3FF:FE1E:8329.
The load balancing method used by the computing resource such as method, round robin, or least weight.

A MAC (media access control) address associated with the resource, such as 06:10:9f:eb:8f:14. Note: Always force lower case on this field. Note: Always use colons instead of dashes, spaces, or no separator.
A name field provided in some data sources.
Represents a node hit.
The number of the destination port on the server that you requested from.
The IP address for the system from which the data originates.
The port number for the virtual IP address (VIP). A VIP allows multiple MACs to use one IP address. VIPs are often used by load balancers.
The operating system of the resource, such as Microsoft Windows Server 2008r2. This field is constructed fromvendor_product and version fields.
The array that the storage resource is a member of, if applicable
The block size used by the storage resource, in kilobytes.
The index cluster that the resource is a member of, if applicable.
The maximum number of file descriptors available.
The latency reported by the resource, in milliseconds.
The path at which a storage resource is mounted.
A higher level object that this resource is owned by, if applicable.
The maximum possible number of blocks read per second during a polling period .
For a polling period, the average amount of time elapsed until a read request is filled by the host disks (in ms).
The total number of read operations in the polling period.
The amount of storage capacity allocated to the resource, in megabytes.
The maximum possible number of blocks written per second during a polling period.
For a polling period, the average amount of time elapsed until a write request is filled by the host disks (in ms).
The total number of write operations in the polling period.
Indicates whether a locally defined account on a resource can be interactively logged in.
Displays the stored password(s) for a locally defined account, if it has any. For instance, an add-on may report the password column from /etc/passwd in this field.
Indicates the shell program used by a locally defined account.
The full name of a locally defined account.
The business unit of the locally-defined user account. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The category of the system where the data originated, such asemail_server or SOX-compliant. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.
The user identification for a locally defined account.
The priority of a locally-defined account.
The hypervisor parent of a virtual guest OS.
The snapshot file size, in megabytes.
The name of a snapshot file.
The time at which the snapshot was taken.
A description field provided in some data sources.
This automatically generated field is used to access tags from within datamodels. Add-on builders do not need to populate it.
Indicates whether thread contention monitoring is enabled.
Indicates whether the JVM supports thread contention monitoring.
Indicates whether thread CPU time measurement is enabled.
Indicates whether the Java virtual machine supports CPU time measurement for the current thread.
CPU-space time taken by the JVM, in seconds.
User-space time taken by the JVM, in seconds.
The JVM's current daemon count.
Indicates whether the JVM supports monitoring of object monitor usage.
The JVM's peak thread count
Indicates whether the JVM supports monitoring of ownable synchronizer usage.
The JVM's current thread count.
The total number of threads started in the JVM.
Process name of the JVM process.
Start time of the JVM process.
Uptime of the JVM process.
The JVM product or service. This field can be automatically populated by the the vendor andproduct fields in your raw data.
Version of the JVM.

Amount of CPU time taken by the JVM.
Amount of free physical memory remaining to the JVM.
Amount of free swap memory remaining to the JVM.
Maximum file descriptors available to the JVM.
Number of file descriptors opened by the JVM.
OS that the JVM is running on.
OS architecture that the JVM is running on.
OS version that the JVM is running on.
Physical memory available to the OS that the JVM is running on.
Swap memory space available to the OS that the JVM is running on.
System load of the OS that the JVM is running on.
Total processor cores available to the OS that the JVM is running on.
Time taken by JIT compilation.
The current count of classes loaded in the JVM.
The total count of classes loaded in the JVM.
The total count of classes unloaded from the JVM.
Committed amount of heap memory used by the JVM.
Initial amount of heap memory used by the JVM.
Maximum amount of heap memory used by the JVM.
Heap memory used by the JVM.
Committed amount of non-heap memory used by the JVM.
Initial amount of non-heap memory used by the JVM.
Maximum amount of non-heap memory used by the JVM.
Non-heap memory used by the JVM.
Number of objects pending in the JVM.

The date of the malware event.
The system that was affected by the malware event. You can alias this from more specific fields, such asdest_host, dest_ip, or dest_name.

Number of entries in the "additional" section of the DNS message.
Resolved address for the query.
Number of entries in the answer section of the DNS message.
Number of entries in the "authority" section of the DNS message.
The destination of the network resolution event. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as dest_host,dest_ip, or dest_name.

The category of the network resolution target, such as email_server or SOX-compliant. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.
The destination port number.
The priority of the destination, if applicable.
The time taken by the network resolution event, in seconds.
Type of DNS message.
The domain which needs to be resolved. Applies to messages of type "Query".
Number of entries that appear in the "Questions" section of the DNS query.
The DNS OpCode name as defined inhttps://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2929#section-2.2.
possible_values: Query, IQuery, Status, Notify, Update, unknown

description: Return code for the response as defined inhttps://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2929#section-2.3.
possible_values: NoError, FormErr, ServFail, NXDomain, NotImp, Refused, YXDomain, YXRRSet, NotAuth, NotZone, BADVERS, BADSIG, BADKEY, BADTIME, BADMODE, BADNAME, BADALG, unknown

description: Numerical id of the return code as defined inhttps://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2929#section-2.3.
The amount of time it took to receive a response in the network resolution event, if applicable.
The source of the network resolution event. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as src_host,src_ip, or src_name.
The business unit of the source. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The category of the source, such asemail_server or SOX-compliant. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.
The port number of the source.
The priority of the source.
This automatically generated field is used to access tags from within datamodels. Add-on builders do not need to populate it.
The unique numerical transaction id of the network resolution event.
The transport protocol used by the network resolution event.
The time-to-live of the network resolution event.
The vendor product name of the DNS server. The Splunk platform can derive this field from the fields vendor andproduct in the raw data, if they exist.
The action taken by the reporting device.
The business unit of the destination.
The category of the destination.

The IP address of the system reporting a network session event. If the system is a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server, this is the lease IP for that server. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The MAC address of the system reporting a network session event. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The name of the Active Directory for the system reporting a network session event, if applicable. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.
The priority of the destination.
The amount of time for the completion of the network session event, in seconds.
The amount of time it took to receive a response in the network session event, if applicable.
An indication of the type of network session event.
The business unit of the source.
The category of the source.

The domain name server of the originator of a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) or DNS event . This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The IP address of the originator of a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) or DNS event. This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The MAC address of the originator of a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) or DNS event . This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.

The Active Directory name of the originator of a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) or DNS event . This field is automatically provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security.
The priority of the source.
This automatically generated field is used to access tags from within datamodels. Add-on builders do not need to populate it.
The user in a network session event, where applicable. For instance, a VPN session or an authenticated DHCP event.
The business unit associated with the user.
The category of the user.
The priority of the user.

The full name of the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) or DNS server involved in this event including vendor and product name, such asMicrosoft DHCP or ISC BIND. This field is generated by combining the values of the vendor andproduct fields.
The duration of the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) lease, in seconds.

The consecutive range of possible IP addresses that the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server can lease to clients on a subnet. A lease_scopetypically defines a single physical subnet on your network to which DHCP services are offered.
The action taken by the network device.
The application protocol of the traffic.
Total count of bytes handled by this device/interface (bytes_in + bytes_out).
How many bytes this device/interface received.
How many bytes this device/interface transmitted.
The 802.11 channel used by a wireless network.
The destination of the network traffic (the remote host). You can alias this from more specific fields, such asdest_host, dest_ip, or dest_name.

These are derived fields provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of certain advanced applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security. They should be left blank when writing add-ons.
The interface that is listening remotely or receiving packets locally. Can also be referred to as the "egress interface."
The IP address of the destination.

The destination TCP/IP layer 2 Media Access Control (MAC) address of a packet's destination, such as06:10:9f:eb:8f:14. Note: Always force lower case on this field. Note:Always use colons instead of dashes, spaces, or no separator.
The destination port of the network traffic. Note: Do not translate the values of this field to strings (tcp/80 is 80, nothttp). You can set up the corresponding string value in thedest_svc field.
The destination priority, if applicable.
The NATed IPv4 or IPv6 address to which a packet has been sent.
The NATed port to which a packet has been sent.  Note: Do not translate the values of this field to strings (tcp/80 is 80, nothttp).
The direction the packet is travelling.
The amount of time for the completion of the network event, in seconds.
The device that reported the traffic event. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as dvc_host,dvc_ip, or dvc_name.

These are derived fields provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of certain advanced applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security. They should be left blank when writing add-ons.

These are derived fields provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of certain advanced applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security. They should be left blank when writing add-ons.

These are derived fields provided by Asset and Identity correlation features of certain advanced applications like the Splunk App for Enterprise Security. They should be left blank when writing add-ons.
Unique identifier for this traffic stream, such as a netflow, jflow, or cflow.
The RFC 2780 or RFC 4443 human-readable code value of the traffic, such as Destination Unreachable orParameter Problem . See the IMCP Type Numbers and the IMCPv6 Type Numbers.
The RFC 2780 or RFC 4443 numeric value of the traffic. See the IMCP Type Numbers and the IMCPv6 Type Numbers.
The total count of packets handled by this device/interface (packets_in +packets_out).
The total count of packets received by this device/interface.
The total count of packets transmitted by this device/interface.
The OSI layer 3 (network) protocol of the traffic observed, in lower case. For example, ip, appletalk, ipx.
Version of the OSI layer 3 protocol.
The amount of time it took to receive a response in the network event, if applicable.

The rule which defines the action that was taken in the network event. Note: This is a string value. Use arule_id field for rule fields that are integer data types (rule_id fields are optional, so they are not included in this table).
The session identifier. Multiple transactions build a session.
The source of the network traffic (the client requesting the connection). You can alias this from more specific fields, such as src_host, src_ip, orsrc_name.
The category of the network traffic source.
The interface that is listening locally or sending packets remotely. Can also be referred to as the "ingress interface."
The ip address of the source.

The source TCP/IP layer 2 Media Access Control (MAC) address of a packet's destination, such as06:10:9f:eb:8f:14. Note: Always force lower case on this field. Note:Always use colons instead of dashes, spaces, or no separator.
The source port of the network traffic. Note: Do not translate the values of this field to strings (tcp/80 is 80, nothttp). You can set up the corresponding string value in thesrc_svc field.
The priority of the source, if applicable.
The NATed IPv4 or IPv6 address from which a packet has been sent..
The NATed port from which a packet has been sent.  Note: Do not translate the values of this field to strings (tcp/80 is 80, nothttp).
The 802.11 service set identifier (ssid) assigned to a wireless session.
The tag associated with the traffic.
The TCP flag(s) specified in the event.
possible_values: Can be one or more of SYN, ACK,FIN, RST, URG, or PSH.

description: The OSI layer 4 (transport) protocol of the traffic observed, in lower case.
The combination of source and destination IP ToS (type of service) values in the event.
The "time to live" of a packet or diagram.
The user that requested the traffic flow.

Designation for a request for change (RFC) that is raised to modify an IT service to resolve an incidentor problem.
The incident that triggered the service request. Can be a rare occurrence, or something that happens more frequently An incident that occurs on a frequent basis can also be classified as a problem.

When multiple occurrences of related incidents are observed, they are collectively designated with a singleproblem value. Problem management differs from the process of managing an isolated incident. Often problems are managed by a specific set of staff and through a problem management process.
The system that is affected by the patch change. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as dest_host,dest_ip, or dest_name.

The patch monitoring product, such asTEM, Patchlink, or SCCM.
Corresponds to an identifier in the vulnerability database provided by the Security Focus website (searchable athttp://www.securityfocus.com/).

The category of the discovered vulnerability, such as DoS. Note: This field is a string. Please use acategory_id field for fields that are integer data type. Keep in mind that thecategory_id field is optional and thus is not part of the CIM.
Corresponds to an identifier in the vulnerability database provided by the US Computer Emergency Readiness Team (US-CERT, searchable athttp://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/).
Corresponds to an identifier provided in the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures index (searchable athttp://cve.mitre.org).
Numeric indicator of the common vulnerability scoring system.
The host with the discovered vulnerability. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as dest_host,dest_ip, or dest_name.

Corresponds to a Microsoft Security Advisory number (http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/security/advisory/).
Corresponds to a Microsoft Knowledge Base article number (http://support.microsoft.com/kb/).

The severity of the vulnerability detection event. Specific values are required. Usevendor_severity for the vendor's own human readable strings (such as Good,Bad, and Really Bad). Note: This field is a string. Please use aseverity_id field for severity ID fields that are integer data types. Keep in mind that the severity_id field is optional and thus is not part of the CIM.

The name of the vulnerability detected on the host, such as HPSBMU02785 SSRT100526 rev.2 - HP LoadRunner Running on Windows, Remote Execution of Arbitrary Code, Denial of Service (DoS). Note: This field has a string value. Please use signature_id for numeric indicators. Keep in mind that thesignature_id field is optional and thus is not part of the CIM.

The user that requested the HTTP resource.

The vendor of the vulnerability detection product or service.

A cross-reference identifier associated with the vulnerability. In most cases, thexref field contains both the short name of the database being cross-referenced and the unique identifier used in the external database.
